subject: Re: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4
msgSnippet: ... I d forgot about this. One of the key points of having a testName in the Parameterized Test Case pattern is to solve this very problem, but giving each row
messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:
> David Saff wrote:
> > All,
> >
> > Kent and I thought and coded last night about a mechanism for allowing
> > parameterized test cases in JUnit 4. The results are in the Version4
> > branch of CVS. We'd appreciate your feedback. For a glimpse of the
> > mechanism in action, see org.junit.tests.ParameterizedTestTest.java:
> >
>
> What would the output from this be? i.e. what does it look like when the
> test fails? Can I easily tell with which parameter it's breaking? and
> can I easily debug just that case?
>
> One of the things I like about the current JUnit 3 non-parameterized
> approach is that when something does fail, I can immediately reproduce
> it to step through in a debugger. I have occasionally done something
> similar to this mechanism without using generics simply by having an
> array of parameters and a for loop inside the test method. That's great
> as long as everything's passing, but it's much less convenient when
> something fails.

I'd forgot about this. One of the key points of having a testName in the
Parameterized Test Case pattern is to solve this very problem, but
giving each row of input/expected output data a name. I imagine adding a
name is not that hard.

@Parameters data = new Object[][] { {"testZero", 0, 5}, ... }

I don't know about autoboxing works in Java, so that might be wrong.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
2005 Gordon Pask Award Winner for contribution to Agile practice
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
